Patch Set 18: Code-Review+2
Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 4e338b2313f9f2a91aa1fb36693e36a328d58933
Just to be clear, we don't really need to do this anymore, right?  the only thing we needed to do was https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/bmcweb/+/72150/2?usp=related-change
That's not to say we shouldn't still remove it;  just that I don't think it blocks your other change.

This is an insecure method for image download via tftp which was only enabled by IBM using insecure-tftp-update feature flag. I checked with @Andrew and they don't use this feature anymore https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/855566794994221117/1250430728945143878 and has been removed via https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc/+/72053.
Since, there is no active user of tftp based updates upstream, it seems better to retire this flow rather than adding support for new DBus interface. In future, we can add support for HTTP based downloads as a new feature (not supported at the moment).

> retire this flow

HTTP/HTTPS pull updates would follow the same flow though?  If we completely retire it, how would we support those in the future (Which as you can see from the patch history i've been working on).

I was intending to follow the same flow as TFTP, but if your goal is to remove TFTP entirely, how would you suggest implementing it instead?

With StartUpdate D-Bus API i don't think we can use the current flow as current flow goes through multiple apps - BMCWeb -> downloadManager -> CodeUpdater. The idea was to deprecate the tftp path since no one uses it and then brainstorm how we should implement this for HTTP flow using D-Bus interface.

The current distributed flow works because only one update at a time and that too only BMC update is supported, so task handler knows which activation interface to watch for on D-Bus.

In general, the main actions for HTTP flow can be -
1. Create Task and return to user.
2. Asynchronously download the Image.
3. Invoke the StartUpdate action with imageFd to CodeUpdater.
4. Watch for activation status changes and update task status.

My understanding is these need to happen in a way so BMCWeb can co-relate the task to the backend to watch for (since BMCWeb is the one to call startUpdate). The critical piece is image download after which we can trigger an update request to CodeUpdater and before which we need to return back to client with TaskInfo.

So, this will probably involve some discussion on how to handle this.

> With StartUpdate D-Bus API i don't think we can use the current flow as current flow goes through multiple apps - BMCWeb -> downloadManager -> CodeUpdater. The idea was to deprecate the tftp path since no one uses it and then brainstorm how we should implement this for HTTP flow using D-Bus interface.
> 
> The current distributed flow works because only one update at a time and that too only BMC update is supported, so task handler knows which activation interface to watch for on D-Bus.
> 
> In general, the main actions for HTTP flow can be -
> 1. Create Task and return to user.
> 2. Asynchronously download the Image.
> 3. Invoke the StartUpdate action with imageFd to CodeUpdater.
> 4. Watch for activation status changes and update task status.
> 
> My understanding is these need to happen in a way so BMCWeb can co-relate the task to the backend to watch for (since BMCWeb is the one to call startUpdate). The critical piece is image download after which we can trigger an update request to CodeUpdater and before which we need to return back to client with TaskInfo.
> 
> So, this will probably involve some discussion on how to handle this.

Right, my assumption was that the existing TFTP flows already do steps 1-4.  If you'd prefer to talk about this in a different forum (not this patch) I'm happy to do talk about it there, but I'd just like to understand the path for an http pull feature in the new model.

Sure, i have created a BMCWeb issue to discuss on this topic https://github.com/openbmc/bmcweb/issues/281 and added more details.

Please let me know if you are fine with merging this change?

> Please let me know if you are fine with merging this change?

Once we have an understanding of how general push updates fit in this new architecture.  Previously they were going to follow the TFTP model, so I don't want to remove the TFTP model until there's an understanding of how the new model handles the same task.

Sure, let's discuss this here since this change is the one removing the current tftp flow.

> Right, my assumption was that the existing TFTP flows already do steps 1-4. If you'd prefer to talk about this in a different forum (not this patch) I'm happy to do talk about it there, but I'd just like to understand the path for an http pull feature in the new model.

The existing flow doesn't do Step3 as such, instead that Step3 in current flow is "CodeUpdater gets notified for new image (for watch) on /tmp/images"

Also Step 4 in current flow is "BMCWeb watch for *any* activation status interface since there is only one activation interface". 

Step2 in current flow is performed by DownloadManager.

To stitch this flow i see following option as suitable, unless you think there is any better way?

a) BMCWeb received HTTP pull request -> b) Created Task and returned to User -> c) Download Image In Task Callback -> d) Trigger Start Update to the client In Task Callback(Receives back the object_path) -> e) Watch for activation status In Task Callback (using earlier returned object_path) 

All the steps a) - e) shall be done in BMCWeb.

> Download Image In Task Callback

What does this mean?  what daemon is doing the download?  It shouldn't be bmcweb, bmcweb should just be "starting" the update on another service.  In your design, which service would that be?

> > Download Image In Task Callback
> 
> What does this mean?  what daemon is doing the download?  It shouldn't be bmcweb, bmcweb should just be "starting" the update on another service.  In your design, which service would that be?

This is what i am thinking we can do -

1) Add a new HTTP.interface.yaml with -
1.a) Method - downloadImage(URI), which accepts a HTTP URL and immediately returns a memfd and asynchronously starts the HTTP download.
1.b) Signal - DownloadFinished(memfd), event which informs that the download has finished for specified memfd.

2) In BMCWeb, for HTTP download use case create task and return a task id to user. In task callback -
2.a) Call downloadImage(URI) from Step#1.
2.b) Perform a dup on the return memfd.
2.c) Watch for DownloadFinished signal for memfd (returned from Step 2.a).
2.d) On download completion call startUpdate as a regular flow.

So, basically for Image download use case we will extend the task callback to also perform the download.

> > > Download Image In Task Callback
> > 
> > What does this mean?  what daemon is doing the download?  It shouldn't be bmcweb, bmcweb should just be "starting" the update on another service.  In your design, which service would that be?
> 
> This is what i am thinking we can do -
> 
> 1) Add a new HTTP.interface.yaml with -
> 1.a) Method - downloadImage(URI), which accepts a HTTP URL and immediately returns a memfd and asynchronously starts the HTTP download.
> 1.b) Signal - DownloadFinished(memfd), event which informs that the download has finished for specified memfd.

Which daemon implements this interface?

> 
> 2) In BMCWeb, for HTTP download use case create task and return a task id to user. In task callback -
> 2.a) Call downloadImage(URI) from Step#1.
> 2.b) Perform a dup on the return memfd.
> 2.c) Watch for DownloadFinished signal for memfd (returned from Step 2.a).

I'm not quite following, why would bmcweb track download finished?  Isn't this flow being done in another application somewhere?

> 2.d) On download completion call startUpdate as a regular flow.
> 
> So, basically for Image download use case we will extend the task callback to also perform the download.

> > > > Download Image In Task Callback
> > > 
> > > What does this mean?  what daemon is doing the download?  It shouldn't be bmcweb, bmcweb should just be "starting" the update on another service.  In your design, which service would that be?
> > 
> > This is what i am thinking we can do -
> > 
> > 1) Add a new HTTP.interface.yaml with -
> > 1.a) Method - downloadImage(URI), which accepts a HTTP URL and immediately returns a memfd and asynchronously starts the HTTP download.
> > 1.b) Signal - DownloadFinished(memfd), event which informs that the download has finished for specified memfd.
> 
> Which daemon implements this interface?

The download Manager which already implements the tftp interface https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt/download_manager.hpp?r=1e9a5f1a.

> 
> > 
> > 2) In BMCWeb, for HTTP download use case create task and return a task id to user. In task callback -
> > 2.a) Call downloadImage(URI) from Step#1.
> > 2.b) Perform a dup on the return memfd.
> > 2.c) Watch for DownloadFinished signal for memfd (returned from Step 2.a).
> 
> I'm not quite following, why would bmcweb track download finished?  Isn't this flow being done in another application somewhere?

BMCWeb needs to initiate the startUpdate once the download has finished, so once it receives the signal for download finished from new HTTP download interface it will trigger the update using the returned memfd.

> 
> > 2.d) On download completion call startUpdate as a regular flow.
> > 
> > So, basically for Image download use case we will extend the task callback to also perform the download.

> > > > > Download Image In Task Callback
> > > > 
> > > > What does this mean?  what daemon is doing the download?  It shouldn't be bmcweb, bmcweb should just be "starting" the update on another service.  In your design, which service would that be?
> > > 
> > > This is what i am thinking we can do -
> > > 
> > > 1) Add a new HTTP.interface.yaml with -
> > > 1.a) Method - downloadImage(URI), which accepts a HTTP URL and immediately returns a memfd and asynchronously starts the HTTP download.
> > > 1.b) Signal - DownloadFinished(memfd), event which informs that the download has finished for specified memfd.
> > 
> > Which daemon implements this interface?
> 
> The download Manager which already implements the tftp interface https://grok.openbmc.org/xref/openbmc/phosphor-bmc-code-mgmt/download_manager.hpp?r=1e9a5f1a.

Gotcha, so we're not getting rid of that interface, only the bmcweb side?  Understood.

> 
> > 
> > > 
> > > 2) In BMCWeb, for HTTP download use case create task and return a task id to user. In task callback -
> > > 2.a) Call downloadImage(URI) from Step#1.
> > > 2.b) Perform a dup on the return memfd.
> > > 2.c) Watch for DownloadFinished signal for memfd (returned from Step 2.a).
> > 
> > I'm not quite following, why would bmcweb track download finished?  Isn't this flow being done in another application somewhere?
> 
> BMCWeb needs to initiate the startUpdate once the download has finished, so once it receives the signal for download finished from new HTTP download interface it will trigger the update using the returned memfd.

This is a problem......  bmcweb shouldn't really be involved in the update state machine aside from handing off the information to the hander.

> 
> > 
> > > 2.d) On download completion call startUpdate as a regular flow.
> > > 
> > > So, basically for Image download use case we will extend the task callback to also perform the download.
https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/webui-vue/+/71937 is removing it from the webui-vue.
Done
How is the message you get by calling doTftpUpdate any different than this message here?
Done. Removed doTftpUpdate and fallback to this error.
